title: History of the Boeing 737 Family
content: The Boeing 737 first flew in 1967 and has become the best-selling commercial aircraft in history with over 11,000 deliveries. The original 737-100 and -200 series were short-range jets seating around 100 passengers. The Classic series (737-300, -400, -500) introduced CFM56 engines in the 1980s. The Next Generation series (737-600 through -900ER) brought a redesigned wing, glass cockpit, and improved range starting in 1997. The 737 MAX introduced LEAP-1B engines and split-tip winglets beginning in 2017.

title: CFM56-7B Turbofan Engine
content: The Boeing 737 NG is powered by two CFM International CFM56-7B turbofan engines, each producing between 19,500 and 27,300 pounds of thrust depending on the variant. The CFM56-7B has a bypass ratio of 5.1:1 and incorporates a wide-chord fan, double-annular combustor for reduced emissions, and full-authority digital engine control (FADEC). The engine has an exceptional reliability record with dispatch rates exceeding 99.95 percent. Each engine features a unique flat-bottomed nacelle designed to provide ground clearance on the 737's short landing gear.

title: 737 Winglets and Fuel Efficiency
content: Boeing offers two winglet options for the 737 NG: blended winglets and the newer split-tip winglets (also called Split Scimitar Winglets). Blended winglets are smooth curved extensions at the wingtip that reduce induced drag by disrupting the wingtip vortex that forms as high-pressure air from below the wing curls around the tip. They provide approximately 4 to 5 percent fuel savings on longer routes. Split-tip winglets add an additional downward-pointing ventral strake, improving fuel efficiency by an extra 1.5 percent. These improvements translate to reduced fuel burn, lower emissions, and increased range.

title: 737 NG Glass Cockpit
content: The 737 NG cockpit represents a significant evolution from earlier 737 variants, replacing most analog instruments with six large flat-panel LCD displays. The flight deck features a common display system showing primary flight data, navigation, engine instruments, and system synoptics. Despite the digital upgrade, Boeing retained the control yoke rather than a sidestick, maintaining commonality for pilots transitioning from earlier 737 models. The overhead panel retains traditional switch layouts for systems management, and the center pedestal houses the throttle quadrant and communication radios.

title: 737 Hydraulic Systems
content: The Boeing 737 NG uses two primary hydraulic systems, System A and System B, operating at 3,000 PSI. Each system independently powers flight controls, landing gear, flaps, and brakes with overlapping coverage for redundancy. A standby hydraulic system provides backup power for rudder, thrust reversers, and leading edge devices if both primary systems fail. The hydraulic pumps are driven by the engines and supplemented by electric motor-driven pumps. This triple-redundant design ensures that no single hydraulic failure can compromise flight safety.

title: 737 Electrical Power Generation
content: Each engine on the 737 NG drives an integrated drive generator (IDG) producing 90 kVA of 115V AC power at a constant 400 Hz frequency. The two generators normally power their respective AC buses independently, but a bus-tie system allows one generator to power the entire aircraft if needed. An auxiliary power unit (APU) provides ground electrical power and backup in flight. The aircraft also carries a battery for essential bus power and emergency standby instruments. A transformer-rectifier converts AC to 28V DC for avionics and lighting systems.

title: 737 Fuel Tanks and Capacity
content: The 737-800 carries fuel in three tanks: two wing tanks and a center tank located in the wing center section beneath the cabin floor. Total usable fuel capacity is approximately 6,875 US gallons (26,020 liters). Fuel is fed to the engines by boost pumps in each tank, with a crossfeed valve allowing either engine to draw from any tank. The fuel system includes a center tank fuel pump override to prevent fuel imbalance. Fuel quantity is measured by capacitance-type sensors in each tank and displayed on the engine indication and crew alerting system (EICAS).

title: 737 NG Safety Statistics
content: The Boeing 737 Next Generation family has established one of the best safety records in commercial aviation history. Since entering service in 1997, the 737 NG has accumulated tens of millions of flight hours with an exceptionally low hull-loss rate. The aircraft benefits from decades of incremental safety improvements, redundant flight systems, and a global fleet-wide operational knowledge base. Airlines and regulators continuously share data through programs like the Aviation Safety Information Analysis and Sharing (ASIAS) system, enabling proactive identification and mitigation of potential safety issues across the entire 737 fleet.

title: Control Yoke vs Sidestick Design
content: Boeing aircraft use a traditional control yoke (a U-shaped wheel on a column) rather than the sidestick used by Airbus. The yoke provides direct mechanical feedback between both pilot positions because both columns are physically connected, so the captain can feel the first officer's inputs and vice versa. This tactile interconnection enhances crew coordination and situational awareness. The yoke requires more cockpit space and adds weight compared to a sidestick, but Boeing values the feedback advantages. The yoke also allows the pilot to apply large pitch and roll inputs simultaneously with one hand while managing thrust with the other, which some pilots find more intuitive during demanding maneuvers.

title: Yaw Damper System
content: The yaw damper is an automatic system that makes small, rapid rudder deflections to counteract Dutch roll, a natural oscillation where the aircraft simultaneously yaws and rolls in a repeating cycle. The yaw damper senses yaw rate using gyroscopes and commands corrective rudder inputs faster and more precisely than a human pilot could. On the 737, the yaw damper operates through the main rudder power control unit and is engaged for all phases of flight above approximately 1,000 feet. Failure of the yaw damper is not dangerous but makes the ride uncomfortable and increases pilot workload, requiring manual rudder coordination during turns.

title: Dutch Roll Aerodynamic Phenomenon
content: Dutch roll is a coupled lateral-directional oscillation where the aircraft alternately yaws and rolls in a repeating motion resembling a pendulum swinging in two planes simultaneously. It occurs because swept-wing aircraft have more roll stability (dihedral effect) than yaw stability (directional stability). When the aircraft yaws to one side, the advancing wing generates more lift, causing a roll. The resulting sideslip then reverses the yaw, creating the oscillation. The phenomenon is named after the resemblance to a Dutch skating technique. Yaw dampers automatically suppress Dutch roll on modern aircraft, but pilots must be trained to recognize and manually dampen it if the yaw damper fails.

title: 737 Rudder System Safety Improvements
content: Following two fatal accidents in the 1990s attributed to rudder power control unit malfunctions, Boeing completely redesigned the 737 rudder system. The original single-panel rudder with a single power control unit was replaced with a dual-input servo valve that prevents the rudder from moving in the opposite direction to pilot command. The 737 NG incorporates this improved design along with a rudder system enhancement program that includes redundant input paths, force limiters, and independent pressure sources. These changes made the 737 NG rudder system one of the most thoroughly analyzed and safeguarded systems in commercial aviation.

title: Horizontal Stabilizer Trim System
content: Unlike many aircraft that use trim tabs on the elevator, the 737 uses a movable horizontal stabilizer for pitch trim. The entire horizontal tail surface pivots on a jackscrew mechanism to change its angle of incidence, providing powerful trim authority. Pilots set trim using thumb switches on the yoke or a trim wheel on the center pedestal. The stabilizer trim system is also used by the autopilot and speed trim system to maintain pitch attitude. The jackscrew is a critical component, and regular lubrication and inspection are mandatory maintenance items. Runaway stabilizer trim is addressed through a well-practiced cutout procedure that disconnects electric trim and allows manual trimming using the trim wheels.

title: Roll Augmentation with Spoilers
content: On the 737, flight spoilers supplement the ailerons for roll control, particularly at high speeds where aileron authority alone may be insufficient or where large aileron deflections could cause wing twist (aeroelastic effects). When the pilot turns the control wheel, the flight spoilers on the descending wing rise proportionally to assist the roll. This asymmetric spoiler deployment increases the roll rate and reduces the aileron deflection needed, decreasing structural loads on the wing. At low speeds during approach and landing, both ailerons and spoilers work together to provide the maximum roll authority needed for crosswind corrections and go-around maneuvers.

title: Ground Spoiler Auto-Deploy System
content: The 737's ground spoiler system automatically deploys all spoiler panels to their maximum angle when certain conditions are met after landing: the aircraft must be on the ground (sensed by main gear weight-on-wheels switches), the throttles must be at idle, and the ground spoiler lever must be armed. This automatic deployment dumps wing lift within one second of touchdown, transferring the aircraft's full weight to the wheels for maximum braking effectiveness. Ground spoilers can increase braking efficiency by up to 60 percent on a wet runway compared to brakes alone. The system can also be armed for rejected takeoffs, deploying automatically if the throttles are retarded to idle above 60 knots.

title: Attitude Indicator on the PFD
content: The attitude indicator, displayed prominently in the center of the PFD, shows the aircraft's orientation relative to the horizon. A blue region represents sky and a brown region represents ground, divided by a horizon line. Aircraft pitch is shown by the position of the aircraft symbol relative to the horizon line, with graduated pitch bars marking each 2.5, 5, and 10 degrees. Bank angle is shown by a pointer at the top referencing a fixed arc with marks at 10, 20, 30, 45, and 60 degrees. The flight director command bars overlay the attitude display, showing the pilot where to point the aircraft to follow the selected autopilot mode. This single display replaces the traditional mechanical attitude indicator, directional gyro, and slip indicator of older cockpits.

title: 737 Autoflight System Architecture
content: The 737 NG autoflight system consists of two flight director systems, a single autopilot, and an autothrottle. The flight director computes commands displayed as crosshair bars on the PFD, showing the pilot how to fly the selected mode. The autopilot physically moves the controls to follow these commands, with capability for single-channel approach and go-around. For autoland in Category IIIA conditions, both flight directors must be operational. The autothrottle maintains speed or thrust targets by moving the thrust levers through servo motors. The entire system is controlled through the mode control panel on the glareshield, with mode annunciations displayed on the flight mode annunciator above each PFD.

title: Takeoff Flap Settings and Configuration
content: The 737 offers multiple takeoff flap settings, typically flaps 1, 5, 10, 15, or 25, selected based on runway length, obstacles, aircraft weight, and temperature. Lower flap settings reduce drag and improve climb performance but require higher takeoff speeds and longer runway distances. Higher flap settings reduce takeoff speed and ground roll but limit the initial climb gradient due to increased drag. The FMC calculates V-speeds for each configuration, and pilots select the optimal setting during pre-flight planning. A takeoff configuration warning horn sounds if the aircraft is not properly configured for takeoff when thrust is advanced, checking flap position, trim setting, speedbrake, and parking brake.

title: Oleo Strut Shock Absorber
content: The nose gear on the 737 uses an oleo-pneumatic shock strut to absorb landing impacts and taxi loads. The oleo strut works like a telescoping cylinder filled with hydraulic fluid and compressed nitrogen gas. During landing, the strut compresses as fluid is forced through a small orifice, converting the impact energy into heat. The nitrogen gas acts as a spring, providing the restoring force to extend the strut back to its normal position. The strut extension is checked during the pre-flight walk-around; proper extension indicates correct servicing. Oleo struts are remarkably durable, often lasting the life of the aircraft with periodic fluid and gas servicing.

title: Major Engine Component Sections
content: A turbofan engine like the CFM56 consists of several major sections from front to back. The fan section contains the large front fan that produces most of the thrust. Behind it, the low-pressure compressor (booster) and high-pressure compressor squeeze air to high pressure and temperature. The combustion chamber mixes compressed air with atomized fuel and ignites it. The high-pressure turbine extracts energy to drive the compressor, and the low-pressure turbine drives the fan. The exhaust nozzle accelerates the remaining gases rearward. Each section contains precision-engineered rotating and stationary airfoil blades that must withstand extreme temperatures, pressures, and centrifugal forces while maintaining tight clearances measured in thousandths of an inch.

title: 737 Emergency Exit Configuration
content: The 737-800 has eight exits: two main entry doors at the front, two service doors at the rear, and four overwing exits (two on each side). This configuration accommodates up to 189 passengers in a single-class layout. The overwing exits are Type III, measuring 20 by 36 inches, and require passengers to lift and rotate the hatch inward before stepping onto the wing. Exit row passengers must meet specific physical requirements and be willing and able to operate the exit. The 737-900ER adds an additional pair of exit doors behind the wing to meet evacuation requirements for its stretched fuselage and higher passenger capacity. Each exit has corresponding exterior markings and escape path lighting.

title: Emergency Evacuation Slide Systems
content: Each main door on the 737 contains an integrated evacuation slide that inflates automatically when the door is opened with the slide armed. The slides use compressed gas cylinders to inflate in approximately 6 seconds, unfolding into a ramp from the door sill to the ground. Slides at the front doors are typically slide-rafts that can also serve as flotation devices during a water evacuation. The slide arming mechanism is controlled by a lever at each door that flight attendants set to armed before departure and disarmed after arrival. If a door is opened with the slide armed, it inflates immediately and cannot be easily re-packed, requiring maintenance to re-stow it. Slide inflation is tested periodically and the gas cylinders have a limited service life.

title: Onboard Emergency Equipment
content: The 737 carries extensive emergency equipment positioned throughout the cabin. Portable fire extinguishers are located at each flight attendant station and in the cockpit, including a Halon unit for electrical fires. Crash axes and protective breathing equipment are provided for fighting cockpit fires. Medical kits containing medications and diagnostic equipment are stowed in overhead compartments, along with an automated external defibrillator. Life vests are stored under each seat for overwater operations, and additional survival equipment including life rafts is carried on extended overwater routes. Megaphones are positioned at flight attendant stations for evacuation commands. Floor-level emergency lighting activates automatically in a power failure, guiding passengers to exits in darkness or smoke.

title: Radome Design and Weather Radar Housing
content: The radome is the smooth, cone-shaped nose cap that houses the weather radar antenna. It is constructed from fiberglass or composite materials that are transparent to the radar's microwave signals while providing aerodynamic streamlining and protection from bird strikes, rain erosion, and hail. The radome on the 737 contains a flat-plate antenna that mechanically tilts and rotates to scan weather at different ranges and altitudes. The radome surface includes a static discharge system and lightning diverter strips to safely conduct electrical discharges around the radar equipment. Regular inspection checks for delamination, erosion, and moisture ingress that could degrade radar performance. A damaged radome can attenuate radar signals, potentially masking hazardous weather returns.

title: Boeing Sky Interior Design
content: The Boeing Sky Interior, introduced as an option for the 737 NG and standard on later builds, features sculpted sidewalls and window reveals that create a greater sense of space. LED mood lighting allows airlines to program different color schemes for boarding, cruise, and arrival, simulating natural sky colors from sunrise to sunset. The overhead bins use a pivot design that opens downward, allowing passengers to load bags at shoulder height rather than lifting them overhead. The bins also offer significantly more volume than the original stowage compartments. The interior includes improved air flow distribution through individual gaspers above each seat and noise-reducing sidewall panels that make the cabin noticeably quieter.

title: Altimetry and Altitude Measurement
content: Aircraft altitude is measured using the static pressure from the pitot-static system. As the aircraft climbs, atmospheric pressure decreases predictably, and the altimeter converts this pressure reading into altitude using the International Standard Atmosphere model. Pilots set the local barometric pressure (QNH) on the altimeter to correct for weather-related pressure variations, ensuring accurate altitude readings relative to sea level. Above a transition altitude (typically 18,000 feet in the US), all aircraft switch to a standard pressure setting of 29.92 inches of mercury, ensuring consistent altitude separation between aircraft. Radio altimeters supplement barometric altitude by transmitting radio waves toward the ground and measuring the return time, providing precise height above terrain for approach and landing.

title: Pressure-Based Flight Instruments
content: Static ports supply ambient atmospheric pressure to three critical flight instruments. The altimeter uses static pressure to determine altitude above a reference datum. The vertical speed indicator measures the rate of change of static pressure to show climb or descent rate in feet per minute. The airspeed indicator compares pitot total pressure against static pressure to determine indicated airspeed. The 737 has static ports on both sides of the fuselage to average out any sideslip-induced pressure errors. An alternate static source inside the cockpit provides backup if external ports become blocked by ice or contamination. Accurate static pressure is so critical that even a small blockage can cause dangerously erroneous instrument readings.
